Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ed.617 - Caribbean Swamp EN (EN -- CR)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ed.617 - Caribbean Swamp EN (EN -- CR)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.Ed.617 - Caribbean Swamp' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.Ed Caribbean & Central American Flooded & Swamp Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: La precipitación media anual es de> 1200 mm. Temperatura media anual oscila entre 22- 23°C. Los suelos son generalmente turbas o barro, o suelos húmedos de piedra caliza de influencia. pH varía de un tanto ácido a alcalino, con poca materia orgánica. Pobres en nutrientes. 5.- Suelo de turba o tierra caliza

Biotic-processes.Summary: Bosques de humedales de agua dulce. 5.- Llanura Costera inundada estacionalmente y semipermanente saturadas. Bosques de 8-15 m de altura.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Classification-system.Classification-element: 1.A.4.Ed Caribbean & Central American Flooded & Swamp Forest

Distribution.Summary: 5.- Palmar Pantanoso Costero del Caribe Sur de la Florida, Cuba y Puerto Rico, y posiblemente otras islas del Caribe
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Trinidad and Tobago moist forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Southeastern conifer and broadleaf forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ed.619 - Mesoamerican Coastal Plain Swamp VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ed.619 - Mesoamerican Coastal Plain Swamp VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.Ed.619 - Mesoamerican Coastal Plain Swamp' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.Ed Caribbean & Central American Flooded & Swamp Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Los bosques que se encuentran cerca al oceano tienen una altura entre los 10-15 m y generalmente estan dominados por la palma Raphia taedigera. Los bosques que estan mas al interior estan sobre lugares que se inundan periodicamente y son mas diversos.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Classification-system.Classification-element: 1.A.4.Ed Caribbean & Central American Flooded & Swamp Forest

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. pantanoso e inundable de estuario Se encuentra desde el norte de Ecuador hasta ambas costas de America Central. Hay dos tipos: los que se encuentran cerca al oceano con mayor salinidad y dinamica de mareas asosiados a lagunas costeras inundadas la mayor parte del año y solo se encuentran desde el noreste de Colombia hasta Nicaragua. Los que se encuentran en el interior con aguas salina salobre.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Central American Atlantic moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Chiapas moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Costa Rican seasonal moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Trinidad and Tobago moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sonoran-Sinaloan transition subtropical dry forest'
WWF ecoregion 'Gulf of California xeric scrub'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.4.Ed.619 - Mesoamerican Coastal Plain Swamp' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criteria.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ed.620 - Mesoamerican Floodplain Forest NT'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.Ed.620 - Mesoamerican Floodplain Forest NT'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.Ed.620 - Mesoamerican Floodplain Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.Ed Caribbean & Central American Flooded & Swamp Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Clima varia entre muy humedo a estacional Suelos aluviales mal drenados a lo largo de los rios. Algunos de estos bosques se presentan sobre suelos calcareos

Biotic-processes.Summary: Los bosques que se encuentran en las llanuras aluviales estan influenciados por el periodo de inundación y esto afecta su composición y estructura de las comunidades. En suelos aluviales la vegetacion se presenta como bosques pantanosos, el sub-dosel presenta raices de zancos y numerosas palmeras en el sotobosque.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Classification-system.Classification-element: 1.A.4.Ed Caribbean & Central American Flooded & Swamp Forest

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq inundable estacional Se distribuye en las llanuras aluviales desde el Golfo del Uraba en Colombia, Panamá, Costa Rica, Nicaragua y Hondurasy en algunas zonas de Belice y Guatemala.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Central American Atlantic moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Chiapas moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Costa Rican seasonal moist forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.
